content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Identify a Specialization on Coursera that focuses on 'Human Resource', list the courses included in this Specialization, and the institution offering it.  Please interact with https://www.coursera.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current page is a promotional landing page for Coursera Plus and does not display a search bar or navigation menu to begin searching for 'Human Resource' Specializations. I need to scroll down to find a navigation or search feature that allows me to look up relevant Specializations on Coursera.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.05
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I still do not see a search bar or navigation menu that will allow me to look for Specializations in Human Resource. I should continue scrolling down to try to access the site’s navigation or search capabilities.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.10
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There is a section showing featured Specializations and Certificates, but none are related to Human Resource. There is a "Show 8 more" button, which may expand the list and potentially display Specializations focused on Human Resource.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The newly revealed options do not show any Human Resource related Specializations; the displayed options still cover Python, Prompt Engineering, AI, and Data Science. I need to scroll further down to look for relevant Specializations or a search bar to directly find 'Human Resource' options.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.20
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The newly loaded courses include topics like Project Management, SQL, Cybersecurity, Generative AI, and Leadership, but none are focused on Human Resource. There still does not appear to be a search box to help narrow results. I should continue scrolling to locate a search feature or more relevant Specializations.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.88
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have now found a search box labeled "Search by keyword", which is the appropriate tool to find Specializations related to 'Human Resource'. I should type "Human Resource" into this search box to locate relevant Specializations.
Action: Type [9]; Human Resource
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search term "Human Resource" has been entered into the search box, but the search hasn’t been executed yet. I need to click the "Search" button to display relevant Specializations.
Action: Click [10]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.40
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search input still contains "Human Resource," but the search has not been activated since the search results have not changed. I need to click the "Search" button (magnifying glass) to see Specializations related to Human Resource.
Action: Click [11]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search for "Human Resource" has still not been executed, as the interface and displayed results remain unchanged. I must click the search button (magnifying glass) to trigger the search operation.
Action: Click [11]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search results have not updated to show Specializations related to "Human Resource"—the two visible are for programming and Excel skills, which are not relevant. The search textbox still contains the correct query, so there may be a delay or the search did not trigger properly. I should scroll down in case new results have loaded outside the initial viewport.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.50
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search results have loaded, and there is a relevant Specialization titled "Human Resource Management: HR for People Managers" offered by the University of Minnesota. To list the courses included in this Specialization, I should click on this result to view more details about its curriculum.
Action: Click [8]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Human Resource Management: HR for People Managers" Specialization by the University of Minnesota is visible and is the correct choice. I need to click on it to access the Specialization's page, where I can find and list the courses included in it.
Action: Click [8]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.75
